results.question: Can we admit a resident with a Foley catheter?
results.answer_text: Yes, you can admit a resident with a Foley catheter in an Idaho assisted living facility. Foley catheters are not on the prohibited list for admission. The regulations specifically state that only supra-pubic catheters have a 21-day restriction, not Foley (urinary) catheters [1].
results.full_answer: Yes, you can admit a resident with a Foley catheter in an Idaho assisted living facility. Foley catheters are not on the prohibited list for admission. The regulations specifically state that only supra-pubic catheters have a 21-day restriction, not Foley (urinary) catheters [1].

results.question: Can we admit a resident with a supra-pubic catheter that was inserted 2 weeks ago?
results.answer_text: No, you cannot admit a resident with a supra-pubic catheter that was inserted 2 weeks ago. According to Idaho regulations, a resident with a supra-pubic catheter can only be admitted if more than 21 days have passed since insertion [2].
results.full_answer: No, you cannot admit a resident with a supra-pubic catheter that was inserted 2 weeks ago. According to Idaho regulations, a resident with a supra-pubic catheter can only be admitted if more than 21 days have passed since insertion [2].

results.question: Can we admit a resident with a G-tube that was placed 30 days ago?
results.answer_text: Yes, you can admit a resident with a gastrostomy tube (G-tube) that was placed 30 days ago. According to Idaho regulations, residents with gastrostomy tubes can be admitted if more than 21 days have passed since the insertion of the tube [1]. Since 30 days have passed in this case, the admission is allowed.
results.full_answer: Yes, you can admit a resident with a gastrostomy tube (G-tube) that was placed 30 days ago. According to Idaho regulations, residents with gastrostomy tubes can be admitted if more than 21 days have passed since the insertion of the tube [1]. Since 30 days have passed in this case, the admission is allowed.

results.question: Can we have residents on IV therapy?
results.answer_text: No, you cannot have residents on IV therapy in an Idaho assisted living facility. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents who are receiving continuous total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or IV therapy are prohibited from being admitted or retained in the facility [1].
results.full_answer: No, you cannot have residents on IV therapy in an Idaho assisted living facility. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents who are receiving continuous total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or IV therapy are prohibited from being admitted or retained in the facility [1].

results.question: What about residents with stage 3 pressure ulcers?
results.answer_text: Residents with stage 3 pressure ulcers cannot be admitted or retained in an Idaho assisted living facility. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents with stage III or IV pressure ulcers are explicitly listed as prohibited admissions [2].
results.full_answer: Residents with stage 3 pressure ulcers cannot be admitted or retained in an Idaho assisted living facility. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents with stage III or IV pressure ulcers are explicitly listed as prohibited admissions [2].

results.question: Can we accept residents on ventilators?
results.answer_text: No, you cannot accept residents on ventilators in an Idaho assisted living facility. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents who require a mechanically supported breathing system are prohibited, with the exception of those who use continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) solely for the treatment of sleep apnea [1]. Therefore, residents on ventilators are not allowed to be admitted or retained in the facility.
results.full_answer: No, you cannot accept residents on ventilators in an Idaho assisted living facility. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents who require a mechanically supported breathing system are prohibited, with the exception of those who use continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) solely for the treatment of sleep apnea [1]. Therefore, residents on ventilators are not allowed to be admitted or retained in the facility.

results.question: Can a resident with a tracheostomy live in our facility?
results.answer_text: A resident with a tracheostomy can live in your facility if they are able to care for it independently. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents who require a tracheostomy must be able to manage it on their own to be admitted or retained in the facility [1].
results.full_answer: A resident with a tracheostomy can live in your facility if they are able to care for it independently. According to IDAPA 16.03.22.152, residents who require a tracheostomy must be able to manage it on their own to be admitted or retained in the facility [1].

results.question: Are hospice patients allowed in Idaho assisted living?
results.answer_text: Yes, hospice patients are allowed in Idaho assisted living facilities. Specifically, the regulations permit the admission of hospice patients, including those who are comatose and have been assessed by a physician or authorized provider who has determined that death is likely to occur within thirty (30) days [3].
results.full_answer: Yes, hospice patients are allowed in Idaho assisted living facilities. Specifically, the regulations permit the admission of hospice patients, including those who are comatose and have been assessed by a physician or authorized provider who has determined that death is likely to occur within thirty (30) days [3].

results.question: Can we admit a resident with MRSA?
results.answer_text: Yes, you can admit a resident with MRSA, but only under certain conditions. According to Idaho regulations, residents with MRSA that is not in an infectious stage can be admitted to an assisted living facility [2]. This means that if the MRSA is non-infectious, admission is allowed. However, if the MRSA is still in an infectious stage, the resident cannot be admitted [1]. Always ensure that the resident's MRSA status is confirmed to be non-infectious before admission.
results.full_answer: Yes, you can admit a resident with MRSA, but only under certain conditions. According to Idaho regulations, residents with MRSA that is not in an infectious stage can be admitted to an assisted living facility [2]. This means that if the MRSA is non-infectious, admission is allowed. However, if the MRSA is still in an infectious stage, the resident cannot be admitted [1]. Always ensure that the resident's MRSA status is confirmed to be non-infectious before admission.

results.question: What residents are we NOT allowed to admit in Idaho?
results.answer_text:
In Idaho, you are not allowed to admit residents who require ongoing skilled nursing or care beyond the facility's legally licensed authority. Specifically, prohibited admissions include residents who:

- Have a gastrostomy tube, arterial-venous (AV) shunt, or supra-pubic catheter inserted within the previous 21 days.
- Are receiving continuous total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or IV therapy.
- Require physical restraints, including bed rails.
- Are comatose, unless a physician or authorized prov
results.full_answer:
In Idaho, you are not allowed to admit residents who require ongoing skilled nursing or care beyond the facility's legally licensed authority. Specifically, prohibited admissions include residents who:

- Have a gastrostomy tube, arterial-venous (AV) shunt, or supra-pubic catheter inserted within the previous 21 days.
- Are receiving continuous total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or IV therapy.
- Require physical restraints, including bed rails.
- Are comatose, unless a physician or authorized provider has determined that death is likely within 30 days.
- Require a mechanically supported breathing system, except for CPAP or BiPAP used solely for sleep apnea.
- Require a tracheotomy and cannot care for it independently.
- Are fed by syringe.
- Have open, draining wounds that cannot be contained.
- Have stage III or IV pressure ulcers.
- Have any type of pressure ulcer or open wound not improving bi-weekly.
- Have methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in an infectious stage.
- Have physical, emotional, or social needs incompatible with other residents.
- Present a danger to themselves or others due to violent or self-injurious behavior.
- Are not able to self-evacuate and reside in a facility not in compliance with state and local fire safety standards [1].
